chapter.title: Elements of valuing oneself
chapter.content:
Elements of valuing oneself

Let’s move on to a second factor contributing to self-determination: Learning to value yourself.

Learning to value oneself means being able to accept one’s strengths and weaknesses and then taking responsibility for both successes and failures. This is part of being ready to make one’s way through life.

Valuing yourself may be defined by these elements:

  • accepting who you are;
  • acknowledging and appreciating your unique strengths;
  • respecting your rights and responsibilities; and
  • being good to yourself.

chapter.title: Questions related to valuing oneself
chapter.content:
Questions related to valuing oneself

The questions we would want individuals with LD to answer explore both positive and negative aspects of their experiences.

A self-determined person can answer these questions:

  • How has my learning disability made me stronger?
  • How have I been successful—big or small?
  • How do I make my LD work for me in my life?
  • What are my habits that get me into trouble?

chapter.title: Self-realization yields positive attributes in persons with LD
chapter.content:
Self-realization yields positive attributes in persons with LD

Grappling with LD can make a person:

  • emotionally and mentally stronger;
  • more in tune with others;
  • more resourceful; and
  • more creative.

These are positive attributes once a person has this self-realization. Rather than feeling a global sense of being a poor learner, a person can appreciate areas of strength outside the specific learning disability.

chapter.title: Ideas for supporting individuals with LD to value themselves
chapter.content:
Ideas for supporting individuals with LD to value themselves

Some ideas for supporting individuals with LD to value themselves include:

  • Incorporate cooperative activities that allow individuals to contribute their strengths.
  • Provide specific feedback about what an individual did well, emphasizing what the individual did that helped him or her be successful in the task. Prior to giving feedback, ask the individual to tell you what he or she did that contributed to success.
  • Set up a system whereby participants can self-record progress.

Take a moment to compare your ideas for support with those listed.

After you have compared your ideas, continue on to Planning.
